text: -- next in 71-300, Andrews against the Louisville & Nashville Railroad Company and others.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
He wants the reinstatement or --
No, Your Honor, he does not.
It's definitely -- what would be the measure of damages in the lawsuit?
I think there would be several things, sir, Mr. Justice Brennan.
Then I gather this -- the crux of the liability would be wrongful discharge, is that it?
That's right, Your Honor, under a common law theory.
Before the board I gather -- the board could award back pay, a back pay for wrongful discharge, but nothing in excess of that pay, is that right?
That's right.
Whereas your asking damages which will be more than just back pay?
That's right, it would be post factor as well.
But not in -- wages are limited to lost wages theory, are they not?
That's right Mr. Justice Brennan, plus reinstatement working back at the railroad.
But in your lawsuit, you'd be asking for damages -- well would you specify that again?

Well, general damages being, the measure of damages, of course, we would look to the current trend, see what his wages would have been had he been employed, and what wages he has earned, the difference being the measure of damages that would be retrospective and in post factor, of course it would be a jury question to determine what his future damages might be.
Do you think that he could be never prospective -- prospectively the difference between what he is thinking in another job, what he would have made with the railroad?
Mr. Justice White, I certainly do, I believe.
Even if the railroad said, please come back we'll reinstate you?
Yes sir, Mr. Justice White, I believe that could be done.
And he has the choice of not working for the railroad and have the (Inaudible)

Georgia recognizes a doctrine known as constructive service, where a man makes himself available for work under his employment contract he can remain available and say I am ready to work and you have to pay me.
The railroad says, we would be glad to put you back to work and he says, no I want to keep the other job, but I want you to pay me the difference between my lower wages on the other job?
That's a difficult question, I am not sure is decided by Georgia Law.

If the railroad will put him back to work and if the Adjustment Board would order his reinstatement, but he says, no I don't wanted to be in reinstatement, but I don't how could you claim damages out of the railroad?
Mr. Justice White, I think that's a very difficult question.
Well, you say anyway [Voice Overlap] --
But I would nonetheless, going to the extent I don't think the acts can cut both ways.
No, but Mr. Estes, you say in any event it's a law question, don't you?
Yes sir.

Whatever measure of damages, respective of what might be the limitation if he followed the federal rules to the Adjustment Board, in the courtroom if you are allowed to bring your action under the State Law then you could cover whatever they --
That's right.
Do you think that State Law would govern the -- what he can recover under a contract with the railroad?
Well, to start with Mr. Justice White, I am not sure of this.
Pay for wrongful discharge?
Excuse me?
He had to claim a wrongful discharge?
Yes, Mr. Justice White, he does.
And wrongful under the collective bargaining contract with the railroad?
Yes, Mr. Justice White, it does, but nonetheless I am not sure that, that makes it an action in contract, that is to say an action X contract --
Whether it is or not, what's the governing law or whether or not he has been wrongfully discharged under collective bargaining contract with the railroad?
Equivalent or not there was justification under the contract --
Was it Federal or State Law?
I think its State Law Your Honor, under the Transcontinental & Western Airlines versus Koppal.
Have these questions been mooted in other cases that you know Mr. Estes?
They are mooted --
There have been a lot of these types of cases before?
Yes, Your Honor, there is one case, it's very critical.
That's one I wrote?
I believe so.
Did you call this an election of remedies case?
I think it is now because of the Price case Mr. Chief Justice.
Being an election of remedies case, do you are still contend that you can collect damages for future unemployment, if the railroad tenders the employment to him as Mr. Justice White suggested?
I think that's a question to be determined by Georgia Law and by a Jury, Your Honor. I agree that I think --
By a jury, it's not a legal question?
It may be a mis-question of law, in fact depending on on whether or not the offer is believable.
I suppose the questions we have been putting to you address issues really not before us in this case, is that right?
No, no.
Yes, but if we would overrule Moore --
If you would overrule Moore --
-- and that line of cases that would mean you would have to go with Adjustment Board, wouldn't it?
Not only would Mr. Andrews have to go to the Adjustment Board, Mr. Justice Brennan, you would forever slam the court house door in any other claim --
As I recall the dissenters in Walker thought we should follow that question?
Well, yes Mr. Justice Brennan that was true with several notable exceptions.
What is -- I remember, let me say something, Walker sometimes took 10 years to get through the Adjustment Board, can't they send and enact a statute to --
Speed up remedies --
Has that happened or not?
Yes, Mr. Justice Brennan, it has happened.
[Voice Overlap] five years you mean --
Well even less, say four years or in some places one-and-a-half years.
How exactly -- under the amended statute unlike the situation of the time Price was decided, is it they are now a judicial review of that, both ways?
That is right, Your Honor.
But now under the new statute there is a judicial review, is it there, both the employee as well the railroad may have it?
Well, may it please the Court, I would take the position that a judicial review is not a review they now -- I maybe mistaken but I think that the findings in fact [Voice Overlap] the case --
But we said in Price there was no judicial review at all on the part of -- available to the employee?
Perhaps you did Mr. Justice --
But now there is some at least whatever --

It's my understanding that Mr. Price would not be permitted to re-litigate issues already determined and it would be petitioner's contention, that would be basically the same as now that when a matter once decided would not be re-litigated on factual finding.
But this argument didn't affect the -- they meant that Moore should continue to be effective in situations where it might properly apply?
Absolutely correct, Your Honor.
Let's assume your client wanted reinstatement; could he get it in court?
Could he get a reinstatement in court?
Why not?
Well, I don't believe you can force someone to be employed somewhere.
Well, doesn't the Adjustment Board sometimes give back pay and order reinstatement?
Yes, Your Honor, it does readily.
Can't you get the same kind of relief in court?
No, Your Honor, I think damages, general damages for common law wrong are totally different damages and they can't --
Why couldn't the court order a reinstatement, if the Adjustment Board could?
Well, perhaps, a court could.
My question -- that isn't my question.Is there some legal barrier to the court giving reinstatement or not?
Mr. Justice White, in all probability a court could tell the railroad either it had to hire him or --
You don't think that the Adjustment Board has exclusive jurisdiction for the reinstatement?
No.

Is it your position that even if the Adjustment Board would order reinstatement, the railroad would be free to say we just don't want this particular man working for us, we'll pay him the money, but we don't accept his services?
That's never been litigated to my knowledge, Mr. Justice Rehnquist but that would be my position, yes.
No court of course can order somebody to work for an employer and that's just as the first day of the contract, (Inaudible)
If it please the Court, I would like to reserve the rest of my time for rebuttal.
Very well Mr. Estes.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
Mr. Major, you will have to watch your notes in relation to the microphone, its a little difficult.

And in those committee hearings, a member named George M. Harrison, who probably had as many credentials as a union may have, he was president of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, Freight Handlers, Express and Station Employees and appeared as chairman of the legislative committee of the Railway Labor Association, he said this in substance.
He doesn't have a -- he has no power to go through the Adjustment Board himself, does he?
He does indeed, Mr. Justice Douglas.
He had to go through the Union?
If my understanding of the Act is correct, he has an absolute right to go himself.
No, but in terms of Section 3 (2) says that the request either made by the representative of proctor class of employee or by the carrier?
It is my impression that the 66th Amendment of the Act --
I am reading the 66th Amendment.

Reading 'J' of this Section, it says parties maybe heard even in person by Council or by other representative as they may respectively elect and I would assume that means if a party can be heard in person, a party means an individual rather than the Union, I would guess.
But as I read Section 3 (2), the Amendment of 1966, it receives complaints only by Unions or by carriers?

Mr. Justice Douglas, if that is true then my conception of the Railway Labor Act or my dispute is erroneous because it was my definite impression that not only could it be done, but it was being done daily before the Adjustment Board.

But I just wondered how a Union normally would be the spokesman, if they are reading statement taking care of the interest of the employee in the future, but if the employee wants to put this thing behind him and get out of the business and never go back and work again than the Union is might not be a very good representative of him?
That is always of course a possibility Mr. Justice Douglas.
Well what happens if both the Brotherhood and Management, both decide that this man is ought to be thrown out of his job?
Well he has a contract that probably -- the Brotherhood I wouldn't think would have anymore right to throw him out of the job and then would the Union.
It has always worked and in fact in some instances where man is just is not loved by anybody?
You mean, he gets double crossed by his own Union, is that what you are referring to?
I imagine Congress has figured that would be the exception rather than the rule?

There is no prohibition against him suing his own Union obviously and secondly I don't think that again there is any problem in that regard because if he has a contract right, the Adjustment Board can give him just the same relief as the Court can.
And Union can't violate the contract just to take care of the guy they don't like?
I would not believe they could Mr. Justice Marshall.

Now if I may ask you, assume a railroad worker has a grievance under the contract and they try to settle it on the property and just didn't settlement and neither side takes it to the Adjustment Board, that isn’t -- the only way it gets to the Adjustment Board is if somebody takes it there?
Yes sir.
What I really am asking, may the railroad and the worker together waive the Adjustment Board?
Worker and the Railroad together may enter into a settlement of problems --
Yeah but they don't settle it, but the Railroad says but we don't want to go to the Adjustment Board, you don't want to go to the Adjustment Board, go to Court, we will settle it in the Court.

Your question Mr. Justice White is broader in that your question is may the parties in a situation where administrative exhaustion of remedies is required maybe they waive the exhaustion of administrative remedies?
No, exhaustion administrative remedies required, all the Act says is that somebody can it take it to the board and if somebody takes it the Board, the other party is got to go there too.
Mr. Justice White I'm not sure I'm perceiving your question, but let me express it this way.

If union refuses to go to go the board -- Mr. Justice Douglas was asking if the union refuses to go the board when the employer turns the grievance down, the worker can't go to Court, they can't go to the board.
I am of the opinion that the individual himself can go the board and it is not depended on his union taking it there?
That is what the statute says and in your brief instead it’s just the opposite.
I was --
Employee representative can go --

I thought that the Public law boards were limited to the union but I was always of the impression that the board itself was open to an individual without his union representatives and that my perception of the law.
I have read somewhere in these briefs -- I've read them some time ago, but in the statistics it shows that there are several cases that have been filed by individuals, not by --
I am sure a public law board --
[Voice Overlap] says the remedy, that's 1966 remedy was provided that either a carrier or employee representative would request to the other [Inaudible] to the special board.

Yes, that's a special board, that's a so called public law board, but that's not, that's where -- approaching one member and when I am approaching other member, that is public law board and Your Honor eminently correct that has to be done by the union representative, but to go with the adjustment board itself and one of the definite question, an individual can do without his union going with it.
But, isn't the public law board that had speeded this thing up?
Well, public law board was exactly created by the 66th Amendment for the purpose of speeding it up and they have speeded it up.

So, if the only way an individual union man can go is not to the public law board, but to the adjustment board as a whole you might not get the benefit of the speedy treatment that was contemplated in 1966?
We think exactly he will get the speedy treatment because -- by reference to the table in our brief Your Honor will readily see that the adjustment boards don't have the backlog of cases they had.
And what's the employees feel now on the 66 act?
Exactly the same as the Railroad is --
De novo?
-- it is not the de novo Mr. Justice Brennan.
In another words you are treating the board pretty much as an arbitrator?
Yes, almost exactly on the question of arbitration yes.
And is that true on both sides that on the review – railroad review or an employee review.
The review is equal on both sides and exactly in the same manner.
Thank you, Mr. Major.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
[Voice Overlap] is that can an employee individually go to an Adjustment board?
Your Honor it is my understanding that he cannot, but he can sue his Railroads for failure to do it, I believe there is Supreme Court case on this.
Is it union or the railroad?
I think the employee once he is fired, once he is out in the court, I believe he can sue the union for its failure to adequately represent him and join --
Now, but suppose he wants to go to the adjustment board route, you mean he can't go unless the union will take his case?
Mr. Justice Brennan it’s my impression is that he cannot go himself, representing himself or through his counsel representing him.
Well that -- if that so then what's this case all about.
What this case is all about Your Honor --
What -- if he can't go with his grievances independently of his union does he have administrative remedy then?
May it please Court, we have taken the position that he cannot.
Is that in the record or is this --
There is no record judge, I am awfully sorry, There has been no discovery --
Well now the problem which seems to divide you gentlemen somewhat and I an inclined to say it's confusing to me is important one, something very easy to find out.
It might be dispositive in one respect Mr. Chief Justice.
